description:
Are you ready to take your coding skills to new heights‚Äîliterally? 

Code to the Top is a unique challenge for all 42 students who dare to push limits not just in code, but in altitude. The goal is simple:

üóª Who can code a 42 project at the highest elevation on Earth?

### Rules:
- You must not be alone. At least two people must be physically present at the location where the coding takes place.
- You must provide photo evidence and post it in the official [42 Vienna Slack channel](https://42born2code.slack.com/archives/C05U1PGPQ4V). 
- The photo must clearly show the altitude (via GPS device, signage, or screen).
- It must also show a person actively coding on a laptop at that location.

**Planes, cable cars, or any kind of aircraft or machine do not count. The spot must be fixed on land (mountain peaks, plateaus, etc.).** How you reach the location is up to you‚Äîhike, climb, bike, or teleport‚Äîjust get there and code.

The participant who codes at the highest documented altitude wins eternal glory (**and a cool surprise prize** üèÜ).

Ready to rise above the clouds and leave your mark? üßó‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Code high, code proud.
name: Code to the Top ‚Äì The 42 Altitude Challenge

description:
As already briefly announced in week's 15 weekly newsletter, **from the 1st until the 3rd of July** we will be hosting a short bootcamp called "**Pro Training - AI / Machine Learning using advanced libraries**", the bootcamp lasts three days from **from 09.00 to 17.00**.

The bootcamp will take place in the [House of Digitalization](https://virtuelleshaus.at/en) in [Tulln](https://maps.app.goo.gl/zFoc89fpvDwMEcPSA), where members of WKNO will take part.

Unlike some previously proposed bootcamps, for this bootcamp, it is a necessary **requirement** to have **basic Python programming skills**.
**Theme**: This bootcamp aims to give attendees a practical application of basic machine learning concepts
- ***Details*:** 3 levels of difficulty
   - **Module 0xX**: Introduction to AI projects, like implementing a linear regression model to predict a continuous variable from input data
   - **Module 1xX**: Discovering classification through logistic regression and other more advanced models
   - **Module 2xX**: More advanced AI projects, such as constructing a neural network model for image classification
You will not have to do them all, but to "place yourself" on a level of difficulty based on your previous knowledge on the topic and start from there.
---
We are looking for **8** students who would be interested in participating as attendees, while helping the participants understand how the system and the peer-to-peer work.
Since the bootcamp will take place in Tulln:
- depending on how many cars we have: you could come with us but, if we do not have enough cars/places, than we will buy the train tickets for you,
- and you will get food every day (First day: breakfast, lunch, and snacks - Second and Third day: lunch - Beverages and coffee during the whole training).

Please, register only if you plan to fully attend the 3 days, already have basic Python knowledge, and are willing to help. - Deadline for the registration: Fri 20 June 2025.
_Just to be clear, please note that: no blackhole days will be added to your account if you attend, and no extension will be done to any deadline. Your presence is required all 3 days from 09.00 to 17.00._
name: Pro Training - AI / Machine Learning using advanced libraries

description:
In this course, participants gain a basic understanding of following Agile Development topics. The program is divided in three blocks. Block 1 (LE001) will consist in the four following courses: 

- LE001.1: Agile SDLC (Agile Software Development Life Cycle, Scrum, Extreme Programming) 
- LE001.2: Agile Requirements Engineering (Epics, Features, User Stories,‚Ä¶) 
- LE001.3: Agile Testing (Acceptance Test Driven Development, Exploratory Testing, Session Best Testing, Testing Tours, Specifications by Example, ‚Ä¶) 
- LE001.4: DevOps (Continuous Integration / Delivery / Development) 

This foundational knowledge is crucial for any agile practitioner and provides the basis for subsequent learning parts of this program, the Agile Topics of the 42 Common Core and Specialization Syllabus. Each of these four topics will be covered with a 90min lecture without any hands-on activities. According to Blooms taxonomy these 4 topics covers only knowledge level (K1) remembering & (K2) understanding. 

By the end of this course, participants will have a solid understanding of Agile methodologies, effective requirements engineering, testing practices in Agile, and the integration of DevOps principles into the Agile development process. 

At the completion of the whole program, the participants will receive a certificate from RBI proving that they acquired the basic skills of Agile Engineering. 

### More information about LE001: 

- Duration: 4 weeks (one lecture per week) 
- Number Participants: max. 40 
- Previous Knowledge: None
- Selection for Participation: First Come First Serve 

**Certificate:** RBI Certificate Of Participation (at least 3 LE) 

‚ö†Ô∏è **Please only subscribe if you are able to participate in at least three of the lectures or if you missed some sessions from the last round.** If you can no longer join, make sure to unsubscribe 48 hours before the start of the event. If you need to unsubscribe after this deadline, contact Drucilla.

### When will these courses take place? 

- Agile Software Development Life Cycle: Agile/XP/SCRUM: Thursday, June 5th from 14:00 to 15:30
- Agile Requirements Engineering (ARE): Thursday, June 12th from 14:00 to 15:30
- Agile Testing (ATE): Wednesday, June 18th from 10:00 to 11:30
- **DevOps: Thursday, June 26th from 14:00 to 15:30**

### LE001.4: CI/CD/DevOps 

**Summary:** 

The DevOps lecture covers the integration of development and operations to enhance collaboration, automate processes, and deliver high-quality software faster. Participants will understand the cultural and technical aspects of implementing DevOps in Agile environments. 

**Learning Outcomes:** 
- Grasp the principles and benefits of DevOps. 
- Explore tools and practices for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD). 
- Understand the cultural shift required for successful DevOps adoption. 

### More info about the speaker: 

Rudolf Gr√∂tz has been working in IT for 30 years and has been a passionate software tester since 2008. He is now working as an Agile Engineering Coach in the topic of Test Automation at Raiffeisen Bank International in Vienna and lives with the motto "Test automation is not an act, test automation is a habit!". In addition to various authorships, including one for the iX-Magazin, he organizes the Agile (Test) Automation Meetup in Vienna and also acts as a speaker at conferences such as the Agile Tour Vienna, OOP & German Testing Day. 

**Linkedin**: https://www.linkedin.com/in/rudolf-groetz-6955b9160/
name: Agile Engineering Fundamentals with RBI | CI/CD/DevOps

description:
Join RBI Agile Engineering Testing Day & TestBustersDay ! 

### What to Expect:
- Insightful (and potentially controversial) Sessions:‚ÄØFrom "Less Testing. Better Quality" by Sven Schirmer to ‚ÄúTesting in Production‚Äù by Mykola Gurov.
- Interactive Panel Discussion: ‚ÄØJoin our panelists for a debate on quality versus quantity in testing.
- Personal Journey:‚ÄØ Tamara Josten's "Becoming a Tester - a fairy tale," will give us some insight into which benefits can be gained by hiring career changers using her personal career path as an example.
- Food & Drinks! 

### When will the event take place?
Tuesday, June 24th 2025

### How?
- It‚Äôs a hybrid event, for onsite Participation in Muthgasse register for this event.
- If you want to join online this is the meeting [link](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/meetup-join/19:meeting_MzE1MDQ2MWUtY2U3Ni00MzViLWFkZmMtZDNhODE2M2Y5YzM0%40thread.v2/0?context=%7b%22Tid%22:%229b511fda-f0b1-43a5-b06e-1e720f64520a%22%2c%22Oid%22:%22d1ad77db-31cc-479e-9ba3-a61fba806648%22%7d)

### Where?
The rooms are √ñsterreich1+2 on the ground floor of the RBI Muthgasse building.

This is how you can get there: 
- You can enter the building at Nussdorfer L√§nde 19: https://maps.app.goo.gl/CtRPZgjhsTAAgk4D9
- or Mooslackengasse 12: https://maps.app.goo.gl/WF2NDbxuT42xBX8V7

### Event Agenda
  
- 08:30 - Registration & Doors Open (Speakers: Rudolf Gr√∂tz, Nicol Weghofer)
- 09:00 - Welcome & Introduction (Speakers: David Zeller (RBI), Rudolf Gr√∂tz (TestBusters), Nicol Weghofer)
- 09:15 - Talk: Less Testing, Better Quality 

Extern Speaker: Sven Schirmer

*Why Focus Holistically on Quality for Business Value: In today's fast-paced software development, achieving quality with rapid feedback is crucial. While Generative AI accelerates development, it also increases testing demands, consuming more resources. Focusing only on test quantity doesn't ensure better quality and often isolates QA as the testers' responsibility, rather than a team effort. This leads to inefficiencies, as developers prioritize features over quality, neglecting their role in developer-led testing. Emphasizing holistic quality over test quantity is essential for true business value.*

- 09:50 - Panel Discussion: Less Testing, Better Quality (Moderator: Nicol Weghofer | Panelists: Sven Schirmer, Martin Klonk, Peter Godoviƒç)
- 10:25 - Coffee Break
- 10:45 - Talk: Becoming a Tester - A Fairy Tale 

Extern Speaker: Tamara Josten

*I'd like to share my fairy tale of changing careers, overcoming challenges, and entering the world of testing. Along the way, I encountered helpful allies and formidable foes. This journey taught me that diverse skills and backgrounds strengthen teams and companies. By sharing my story, I aim to highlight the value of hiring career changers and the benefits of an agile learning approach. This transformation not only helped me achieve my dream but also reshaped it, showing that everyone can author their own fairy tale.*

- 11:20 - Talk: Scaling the Heights - Transforming Testing Automation

Speaker: Florin Petre

*In early 2024, the PI Delivery Tribe launched an initiative to revolutionize testing through an Upskilling Testing Automation program. Starting with 25 QA colleagues, it expanded to 135 participants across all delivery tribes. The goals were to upskill 80% of QA staff in test automation and achieve 60% automation coverage for agile products. Despite challenges in stakeholder agreement, budget, and cultural change, support from Group Agile Engineering was crucial to this success story.*

- 12:00 - Lunch
- 13:00 - Welcome Back (Host: Rudolf Gr√∂tz)
- 13:15 - Talk: Testing in Production 

Extern Speaker: Mykola Gurov
 
*Embrace Production as a first-class testing environment to decrease costs and improve quality.
Thorough testing before merging to master is great, but it doesn‚Äôt reveal the unknowns. Staging on shared environments tends to be slow, unreliable and costly to support. Why not just learn from the only true environment by conducting safe and efficient experiments?
This talk is based on my experience of increasing the delivery rate within the context of back-end systems of bol.com (one of the biggest online retailers of the Netherlands; logistics and purchasing domains), where correctness is often a bigger concern than performance, and recovery might require a bit more than users hitting the refresh button of their browser.
Testing on production is often associated with A/B testing or canary releases, but those aren‚Äôt always the best - or even applicable - techniques. We‚Äôll look instead at shadow and dry runs, controlled experiments, survival of the fittest; how to apply these techniques and what to be aware of.*

- 13:50 - Talk: The Road to QA - An okayish success story

Extern Speaker: Benjamin Bischoff
 
*Throughout my career as a software developer, I‚Äôve observed numerous QA professionals transitioning into test automation roles, with some turning into full-fledged developers. My journey, however, took the opposite path‚ÄîI moved from being a developer to specializing in test automation.
In this talk, I aim to delve into why this transition felt like a natural progression for me. I‚Äôll share the lessons I learned along the way and how this shift fundamentally altered my perspective on both developers and QA professionals.
Moreover, I‚Äôll touch on the importance of challenging the status quo and how this significantly enhances career development. By questioning your role, you can uncover opportunities for growth that you might not have considered otherwise.*

- 14:25- Coffee Break
- 14:45 - Talk: Performance Testing

Speaker: Ivan Horvat
 
*Performance testing is an important part of the software development cycle and is constantly evolving. I will discuss our experience, which started with simplistic, sporadic tests and evolved into a system-wide, systemic testing process involving the cooperation and coordination of different IT departments, agile teams, and business owners.*

- 15:20 - Talk: FullStack Consumer Driven Contract Testing with CITRUS

Speaker: Andreas Halwein
 
*Based on my experience in various product teams developing software products and integrating them with systems across organizations and countries, I would like to share some possible tech stacks for automated regression testing at the system test level. 
I will then focus on why you should invest in this and share my lessons learned.*

- 16:00 - Closing Remarks
name: RBI Agile Engineering Testing Day & TestBustersDay

### LE001.3: Agile Testing 

**Summary:** 

This lecture concentrates on the role of testing in Agile environments, emphasizing continuous testing, acceptance test-driven development (ATDD), and automated testing. Participants will gain insights into how testing practices contribute to the overall success of Agile projects. 

**Learning Outcomes:** 
- Comprehend the significance of testing in Agile development. 
- Learn about Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD) principles, exploratory testing, testing tours,... 
- Explore strategies for implementing automated testing in Agile. 

### More info about the speaker: 

Rudolf Gr√∂tz has been working in IT for 30 years and has been a passionate software tester since 2008. He is now working as an Agile Engineering Coach in the topic of Test Automation at Raiffeisen Bank International in Vienna and lives with the motto "Test automation is not an act, test automation is a habit!". In addition to various authorships, including one for the iX-Magazin, he organizes the Agile (Test) Automation Meetup in Vienna and also acts as a speaker at conferences such as the Agile Tour Vienna, OOP & German Testing Day.

description:
In this course, participants gain a basic understanding of following Agile Development topics. The program is divided in three blocks. Block 1 (LE001) will consist in the four following courses: 

- LE001.1: Agile SDLC (Agile Software Development Life Cycle, Scrum, Extreme Programming) 
- LE001.2: Agile Requirements Engineering (Epics, Features, User Stories,‚Ä¶) 
- LE001.3: Agile Testing (Acceptance Test Driven Development, Exploratory Testing, Session Best Testing, Testing Tours, Specifications by Example, ‚Ä¶) 
- LE001.4: DevOps (Continuous Integration / Delivery / Development) 

This foundational knowledge is crucial for any agile practitioner and provides the basis for subsequent learning parts of this program, the Agile Topics of the 42 Common Core and Specialization Syllabus. Each of these four topics will be covered with a 90min lecture without any hands-on activities. According to Blooms taxonomy these 4 topics covers only knowledge level (K1) remembering & (K2) understanding. 

By the end of this course, participants will have a solid understanding of Agile methodologies, effective requirements engineering, testing practices in Agile, and the integration of DevOps principles into the Agile development process. 

At the completion of the whole program, the participants will receive a certificate from RBI proving that they acquired the basic skills of Agile Engineering. 

### More information about LE001: 

- Duration: 4 weeks (one lecture per week)

Focusing on Agile Requirements Engineering, this lecture delves into effective ways of gathering, managing, and prioritizing requirements within Agile projects. Participants will learn how to adapt traditional requirements engineering to the iterative and collaborative nature of Agile.

description:
We are going to Beko's headquarters for another Knowledge Sharing session focused on the legal and ethical aspects of AI. 

### When will it take place? 
Wednesday, June 11th from 14:00 to 16:00 

### Event Information:

Artificial intelligence is changing the world: from self-driving cars to chatbots that communicate almost like humans. However with these opportunities come complex questions. Who is liable if an AI system makes mistakes? How do we prevent discrimination by algorithms? And where do we draw the ethical boundaries? In this session, we will explore how legal frameworks and ethical considerations shape the development and use of AI. Ideal for anyone who wants to understand how these exciting challenges will shape our future.

**Content:**
- Copyright
- Data protection: Processing of personal data by AI
- EU AI Act
- Ethics guidelines
- Practical dos and don'ts ("commandments" and "prohibitions") with a focus on software development

### How do I join? 
Simply subscribe to the event on the intranet. As always, registrations are on a first come-first serve basis and require active participation (See Event Attendance rules [here](https://meta.intra.42.fr/articles/event-attendance)). Please unsubscribe or contact the Bocal if you can no longer come. No shows will result in a Community Service!
name: Knowledge Sharing with Beko |  AI ‚Äì legal and ethical aspects

The discovery piscinie will help you master basic text editors and delve into the essentials of HTML/CSS, JavaScript, and comprehensive website development. In just 5 days, you'll learn to create your own website and craft simple web pages or interactions. Solve problems independently or in groups, conduct research, and adapt to new technologies.

The curriculum includes:

- SHELL, using the terminal to navigate between folders, create files and perform operations.
- HTML and CSS, learning the basics of web development with HTML and CSS languages.
- Javascript, using the language to create interactions on the web page.
As usual in 42, there will be no teachers and learning will be based on peer 2 peer.

There are **8 spots open** for our students and, if you are interested in attending the discovery piscine, please subscribe to this event at the latest within Friday 23/05/2025.

##### Just to be clear, please note that: no blackhole days will be added to your account if you attend, and no extension will be done to any deadline. Each day is related to a different topic, therefore, your presence is required all 5 days from 10.00 to 17.00.

description:
This time, we will be visiting the Headquarters of EVVA in Vienna. 

### What is a Learning Journey? 
Learning Journeys are a great opportunity to have a first-person experience at one of our partners. Join us for a tour of the headquarters, some insights about their work and interesting discussions valuable for your future! 

### When is it going to take place? 
Monday, May 26th from 13:00 to 16:00 

### Program: 
- Reception & Welcome: EVVA company presentation
- Factory tour in two groups: German and English
- Knowledge Sharing: Security in the context of digital product development
	- Pillars of Information Security
		
		‚Ä¢ Authenticity
		
		‚Ä¢ Integrity
		
		‚Ä¢ Confidentiality
	
		‚Ä¢ Non-Repudiation

		‚Ä¢ Availability

	- User View/Developer View/Ops View
	- SecDevOps
	- Topics involved:

		‚Ä¢ CVE's

		‚Ä¢ Secrets Management

		‚Ä¢ Security by design

		‚Ä¢ Privacy by design

		‚Ä¢ Impact of compliance (GDPR CRA/NIS2, EN18031-1)

- Questions, conclusion, reflection, feedback

### More info about EVVA: 
EVVA Sicherheitstechnologie GmbH, founded in 1919 in Vienna, is an Austrian security technology manufacturer for mechanical and electronic locking systems and access controls. The company holds more than 200 national and international patents and has 10 branches all over Europe.

### How do I join? 
Simply subscribe to the event on the intranet. As always, registrations are on a first come-first serve basis and require active participation (See [Event Attendance rules](https://meta.intra.42.fr/articles/event-attendance)). Please unsubscribe or contact the Bocal if you can no longer come.
name: Learning Journey | EVVA

description:
As part of the Career Week event, some small conferences with experts from the corporate partners and 42 students who are currently working will take place. These short talks will focus on company presentations, job profiles, etc... The aim is to give you the opportunity to get to know our corporate partners and get a better overview of what you can do after 42.  

### Event Description: 
Four Junior Developers from [ACL](https://www.acl.at/), [Fronius](https://www.fronius.com/de-at/austria), [Welser profile](https://www.welser.com/en) and [Beko](https://beko.at/) will come on campus to describe their everyday work and answer all of your questions. You'll be able to get a direct insight into the work of (Full Stack, Web) Software Developer. 

### About the speakers: 

The four following developers will be joining the event:

- [Jonas Lorenz](https://www.linkedin.com/in/lorenz-jonas/), ACL
- Clemens Zehetner, FRONIUS
- [Jasmina Sasse](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jasmina-sasse-1a78a714a/), WELSER PROFILE
- Stefan Neuhauser, BEKO

### How do I join? 
Simply subscribe to the event on the intranet. As always, registrations require active participation (See Event Attendance rules [here](https://meta.intra.42.fr/articles/event-attendance)). Please unsubscribe within the deadline or contact the Bocal if you can no longer come.
name: Career Week üíºOne Working Day @ ACL / Fronius / Welser Profile / Beko

description:
Join your peers for an exhilarating week of treasure hunting at this upcoming Geocaching event! 

### What is Geocaching? 
Geocaching is an outdoor activity that involves using a GPS to search for hidden containers, called "geocaches," in various locations around the world. Geocaching combines elements of treasure hunting, navigation, and outdoor exploration. This time, the theme will be "Green Vienna" and will have you discover the green areas and parks around our beautiful city. 

### How will the game go? 
We will first start with an introduction event to explain the rules of the game and form the teams. You will also be given access to a Discord channel with all of the caches that you will need to look for. You will then have a whole week to find as many caches as possible. Each caches are worth a different amount of points depending on difficulty (Easy, Medium and Hard). At the end, the three teams with the most points will get some prizes. üéÅ The game will end on **Friday, May 16th at 15:00**, where we will have another event to announce the winners. 

### Prizes 
- **1st Place**: Geocaching Winner Achievement + 500 Coalition Points + 100 Altairian Dollars + Intranet Title 
- **2nd Place**: 250 Coalition Points + 75 Altairian Dollars 
- **3rd Place**: 125 Coalition Points + 50 Altairian Dollars 

Each participant will also receive a **Geocaching Achievement**.
name: Geocaching Contest | 42 Vienna's Treasure Hunt!

description:
This time, we will be visiting the Headquarters of Welser Profile in Gresten. 

### What is a Learning Journey?
Learning Journeys are a great opportunity to have a first-person experience at one of our partners. Join us for a tour of the headquarters, some insights about their work and interesting discussions valuable for your future!

### When is it going to take place?
Wednesday, May 7th  from 08:30 to 17:30

### Program:
- **9:00 ‚Äì 10:50**: Departure from Campus üöå
- **11:00**: Arrival at Welser and Welcome
- **11:05 ‚Äì 11:20**: Short Presentation by Top Management (Vision and Plans for Welser Profile - Benefits of IT)
- **11:20 ‚Äì 12:15**: Presentation on the topic of IT: Data Science/Data Analytics, e.g. Logistics, AI, etc.*
- **12:15 ‚Äì 13:00**: Q&A with Welser IT experts
- **13:00 ‚Äì 13:50**: Lunch Break
- **13:50 ‚Äì 14:40**: Factory tour
- **14:40 ‚Äì 15:15**: Wrap-up
- **15:15 ‚Äì 17:05**: Return to Vienna üöå

*What the presentations will be about:

Stefan Rotter:
- Chapter 1: data architecture > Welser data stack
- Chapter 2: date model > Welser knowledge graph
- Chapter 3: data product > Allo-X

IT (Anton Vorraber, Manuel Krenn, Christian Wallmann): 
- IT and Dig  inkl Organization
- Cloudjourney @ Welser
- AI@ Welser
- Q&A

### More info about Welser Profile:
Welser Profile is a manufacturer of different profile systems made of steel and non-ferrous metals. The company was created in 1664 in Ybbsitzt, Lower Austria and now employs over 2000 people worldwide.

### How do I join?

Simply subscribe to the event on the intranet. As always, registrations are on a first come-first serve basis and require active participation (See [Event Attendance rules](https://meta.intra.42.fr/articles/event-attendance)). Please unsubscribe or contact the Bocal if you can no longer come.
name: Learning Journey | Welser Profile

description:
In this workshop, [Thomas](https://profile.intra.42.fr/users/tkolar) will show you the basics of testing your code. 

First, we'll look at how Thomas tested his code during the piscine, both as a basic and scrappy way to do it and to demonstrate issues with that basic approach. Then, we'll use the shortcomings we find to motivate Criterion, a bocal-approved (and even bocal-installed!) framework, ie, what you should actually be using.
name: Peer Workshop | Testing - basic concepts and using Criterion
